text: The street-side medical tent carries a faint scent of herbs, white curtains swaying gently in the wind.
Alicia pulls me down onto a stool. “Let them wrap it properly this time.”
She raises an eyebrow. “You nearly left your arm in that forest this morning.”
The apothecary brings clean bandages and fresh water. Alicia takes them herself, deftly removing the old wrap and rebandaging the wound layer by layer.
“When you’re a mercenary, if you can’t treat your own wounds, you die.”
Her tone is calm. She ties off the final loop of bandage.
Her hand lingers over the back of mine for a moment, as if checking whether the bleeding has fully stopped.
“Not anymore. Your hands work better than any medicine.”
She pauses, then lets out a soft laugh. Sunlight slips through the curtain seam, trembling across her lashes.
In that moment, the noise of the town fades away, leaving only the warmth of her palm against mine.
